abrasions.title: Abrasions (Scrapes)
abrasions.description: A skin injury caused by rubbing or scraping against a rough surface.
first_aid_steps: Wash your hands before touching the wound.
Rinse the area gently with clean water to remove dirt.
Clean the wound with mild soap around (not inside) the injury.
Apply an antiseptic.
Cover with a clean sterile bandage.
Change the bandage daily.
when_to_seek_help: If dirt cannot be removed.
If redness spreads or pus appears.
If pain increases after 2–3 days.

bruises.title: Bruises
bruises.description: Blood trapped under the skin due to impact or pressure.
symptoms: Blue, purple, or green skin discoloration
first_aid_steps: Apply a cold pack for 10 to 20 minutes.
Elevate the bruised area if possible.
Rest the injured part.
After 48 hours, use a warm compress to speed healing.
when_to_seek_help: If the bruise is extremely painful.
If swelling gets worse.
If the bruise appears without injury (possible medical issue).

burns.title: Burns
burns.description: Damage to skin from heat, chemicals, electricity, or radiation.
first_aid_steps: Cool the burn under running water for 10 to 20 minutes.
Remove tight clothing or jewelry near the burn.
Cover with a sterile, non-stick bandage.
Take pain relief if needed.
Do not pop blisters.
when_to_seek_help: If the burn is larger than your palm.
If it affects the face, hands, or genitals.
If there is black/charred skin.

cut.title: Cuts (Minor)
cut.description: A break in the skin caused by a sharp object.
first_aid_steps: Apply pressure to stop bleeding.
Rinse with clean water.
Clean around the wound with mild soap.
Apply antiseptic ointment.
Cover with a sterile bandage.
when_to_seek_help: If bleeding wont stop after 10 minutes.
If the cut is deep or gaping.
If caused by a rusty or dirty object.

snake_bites.title: Snake Bites
snake_bites.description: A wound caused by a snake bite. May be venomous.
first_aid_steps: Keep the person calm and still.
Immobilize the bitten limb.
Keep the bite below heart level.
Remove tight items (rings, shoes).
Wash gently with water—do not scrub.
Apply a pressure bandage if the snake is venomous.
Get medical help immediately.
when_to_seek_help: ANY snake bite needs medical help.
If swelling spreads quickly.
If the person struggles to breathe.

ingrown_nail.title: Ingrown Nail
ingrown_nail.description: When the corner of a nail grows into the skin, causing pain and swelling.
symptoms: Redness and swelling around the nail
first_aid_steps: Soak the foot/finger in warm water for 15 minutes.
Lift the nail edge gently with clean cotton.
Apply antiseptic.
Wear open footwear if possible.
Trim nails straight across, not curved.
when_to_seek_help: If infection appears.
If pain becomes severe.
If the ingrown nail keeps returning.

laceration.title: Lacerations (Deep Cuts)
laceration.description: A deep, jagged tear in the skin.
first_aid_steps: Apply firm pressure.
Raise the injury above heart level.
Clean gently around the wound.
Cover with a sterile dressing.
Do NOT close the wound yourself.
when_to_seek_help: If bleeding doesn't stop after 10 minutes.
If the cut is very deep or shows muscle.
If caused by glass or machinery.

tick_bites.title: Tick Bites
tick_bites.description: A bite caused by a tick attaching to the skin.
first_aid_steps: Use fine tweezers to grasp the tick close to the skin.
Pull upward steadily without twisting.
Clean the area with antiseptic.
Apply an antibiotic cream.
Monitor for rash or fever.
when_to_seek_help: If a bulls-eye rash appears.
If fever or fatigue develops.
If tick parts remain in the skin.
